review_title: Customer Success Management at Vonage is awesome!
pros: Customer Success Department management is very supportive and collaborative. Coming from a sales background and wanting to move into something more "farming" than "hunting" this role has been so fun to take on and truly making an impact for not only my customers but for Vonage as a company too. Our CSM department is growing and we have such a great vibe that it's enjoyable to come to work everyday. I love that we have support from all our other internal teams to drive the best customer experience. I feel like I'm part of a start up company with the resources of an enterprise. The company takes the initiative for continual education and feedback which I think is great - and they are receptive to it.
cons: As Vonage has made many changes in the past year to really complete out the offering suite, it has shifted the culture in other departments -however I notice that the company is prioritizing repairing that culture and making it a destination work place overall and not just department by department.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep focus on making each department a destination work place and it will get there. I know the CSM team is already one!!

pros: Great Vision, great benefits, and good technology.
cons: Vonage name not well known in B2B and Vonage relies on dysfunctional channel sales that are sporadic by region. It was hard to get people to look at Vonage over Ring Central, Mitel and even Cisco. The initial training is too short and lacks focus on use cases need to understand value prop. They are getting better but trail several competitors in New England.
advice_to_mgmt: Train your sales people better initially and have more technical sales people in region to support sales team. Need more sales from the channel in New England.

review_title: Very exciting time to part of the Vonage team
pros: Fantastic culture, Excellent training, Great benefits, Innovative organization. Smartest group of people I have ever worked with top to bottom. Work culture is the best I've ever been a part of as well. Striving to always be a destination workplace for all is just part of Vonage's DNA.
cons: None that come to mind.
advice_to_mgmt: Keep up the good work. You are big part of the reason top talent is both attracted to work here and also stay here. Transparent leadership.

review_title: Moving Forward in a Positive Direction
pros: The environment is fast paced and keeps you on your feet. You will always be in learning mode and looking for ways to improve the company through your own department. A lot of change with the acquisitions, but with that change is enormous potential to grow Vonage even further.
cons: Personally, I have not had a poor experience. I have read some of these other reviews and I am a bit surprised. The office I work at is very pleasant and everyone seems happy to be at work.

review_title: Massive Upside with Mid-Term Growing Pains
pros:
Exhilarating to be part of transforming a company at its core.

A start-up like environment with a relatively flat hierarchy.

GSD attitude across most business units.

Good benefits and comp.
cons: Not for everyone! Vonage grew through acquisitions and now feeling integration pains. This is to be expected. After major surgery you don't start running right away -- this is no different. The people that will flourish in this environment are those that are gritty, self-motivated, and comfortable leading in ambiguity.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on listening to employee feedback and implementing substantive programs to improve culture and values.

review_title: had a very difficult time working here
pros:
The training was abysmal. Training was a by-product of people's schedule. If there was time on their schedule for training, then there will be training. There was no training for itself. Absolutely no manuals were given as a reference. You had to rely on asking questions to your peers.

The company atmosphere was infected with the attitude of "I got hired here so I am awesome". Too many people had an inflated sense of themselves. Efforts were made to "prove" how they are better than you. If you made any attempt to seem intelligent about anything, this would be met with scorn. Overall, too much snootiness. Please keeps things into perspective. Too many times I was told that I was just a temp here and not a real employee. Well I will do respect, but I would not classify the job as having a complex nature.
cons: You're just another number that they need 80 hours a week from. Management says they care but actions are disjointed from their words. Overworked and burnt out people make long hours longer. One plus is I did learn a lot. Build your resume and get out.

review_title: Good place to start your career
pros: Made great friends while working
cons: Expanded too quickly for management to keep up

pros: Benefits like 401k, health, stock
cons:
Several top executives have quit over the last 24 months and have been replaced by people hellbent on driving the most lucrative department into the ground. New executives have decided to outsource the inside sales team overseas and completely cut off the marketing budget to squeeze out majority of the department.

Inside Sales went from easily taking 5-10 new leads a day to barely getting 1-3. Its impossible to keep a pipeline and hit quota at this rate. If you dont hit quota, you DO NOT get a commission check - no matter how close you come. If you miss goal 3 times you are fired.

When these concerns are brought to middle management we were told that there will be many people let go over the next few weeks - either fired for not hitting goal or forced to quit due to not making money. We were advised that those who do manage to stay will expect to make 40-50% LESS than we have over the last several years. Even past Presidents Club reps are struggling to make it this month. I've enjoyed working here over the last few years, but it's become very clear that its time to move on.

In addition, there is zero room for advancement. The average age for inside sales is between 25/30 - we have no older colleagues in the inside account executive roles, because you have to go elsewhere for career advancement.

Work/Home life ratio is incredibly difficult if you want time for a family. Even before the cutbacks, many people worked well over 60 hours a week to take extra leads after hours (many worked 9am-9pm plus weekends). Then we slowly had to start working 60+ hours just to stay afloat. Now every new lead coming in goes to a different country and there isnt even an opportunity to stay late and give it your best shot.

But dont worry, there's unlimited time off now.... but not having a job at all also provides ample free time.

Really sad, because direct supervisors are fantastic and always helpful but everyone is feeling the squeeze and will probably jump ship soon.
advice_to_mgmt: Dont go chasing waterfalls.

review_title: Selling work from anywhere Solutions but not using them
pros: It gave me a job
cons:
Vonage Prides itself with its customers on allowing them to work from anywhere. Vonage however does not drink its own Kool-Aid as the CEO likes to use the term, and does not allow its field sales, engineers, etc the ability to work from anywhere, instead they insist on paying for expensive office space.
they recently changed their vacation plan to discretionary time off which is great however they need to allow people the ability to truly work from anywhere and not be locked into a specific Market or office. are Mobility products allow us to truly work from anywhere and most customers generally do not want to meet you face to face except in rare occasions. For those rare occasions travel is the easiest way to go. Save the company money and makes the workforce much more flexible.
advice_to_mgmt:
Vonage please stop being a two-sided coin. if we are going to sell true mobility and flexibility to our customers we need to prove that it works by actually showing them that our Workforce does the same thing. I had a recent customer during a meeting tell us flat out that their Salesforce does not even meet their customers face-to-face because the customers most often do not want to meet face-to-face they would prefer to do it remote. I wholeheartedly agree. This also allows your Workforce to live or work anywhere. I myself have a situation where I need to move to an area where we do not have an office to take care of sick family and have basically been told I will lose my job if I try and move there because I have to be in a local office.
If this is a c-level executive decision that can be amended please reach out to me on this review with contact information and I will contact you. I love working for the company but these two things have forced me at this point to start actively looking for another position that does allow me to flexibility I need.

pros: Training with E was phenomenal. The lessons he bestowed upon me personally and the group I came in with was the most valuable take away. The $15 kiosk money was cool.
cons: Let’s start with lies. The recruiter lied about how much “Top reps” were making. I was told top reps make around 80k but trust me there’s probably 2 to 3 “top OB SDR reps” that performed at a high level *Even some with help from a special list* and NONE of them are touching anywhere close 80k. Now churn rate. I came in with maybe 10-11 people and none of us are there anymore (Only 2 were actually fired the rest of us quit). There was 11 more hires after us and maybe 1-3 are left there now and they’re all looking for something else lol. It’s sad because Vonage has so much potential to be a GREAT company to work for but they have to stop the lies, invest more into the employees and restructure the commission plan. Now Management. Just because you’re a good “SDR” doesn’t mean you have the skill set to manage or lead a team. Out of the 3 supervisors I was around 2 of them were phenomenal and the other just stayed on IG all day.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop allowing recruiters to lie to people & fix the commission structure.

review_title: Read the reviews, the majority are spot on
pros: Nice campus, meal card allowance, flexible work environment, Education reimbursement plan (limited but offered), some other decent benefits, probably a good experience for fresh out students looking to get their feet wet
cons: I was with the company a long time, but unfortunately what was a stable residential B2C telco company has become a very volatile "software company". Constant fears of quarterly layoffs when targets are slightly off, little freedom to influence - purely a top down company, management does not seem empowered, big on do more with less culture, goals never seem aligned company-wide. Some culture clash and friction with acquired companies makes it difficult to move projects forward, specifically some of there operations managers/offices out West. Not much upward movement, most opportunities are lateral or out the door. Little loyalty to the employee, just fuel for revenues. This is purely a product driven company now.
advice_to_mgmt: There are still many talented, tenured Vonage employees who have great vision and understand the customer experience. Companies quick shift out of telco with past acquisitions have left people and systems displaced, and now paying the price. Learned lessons of past management, product heavy vision with no focus on customer experience created many burned bridges and a bad company perception. Fix within, stabilize people and platforms, and see my cons.

pros: The pay and benefits are competitive, with lots of opportunities for overtime if you choose. There are a few slots in the schedule with the possibility of more flexible scheduling. Free snacks are provided. The dress code is casual. You get a few opportunities to learn routing and switch technology and apply them on the job.
cons:
The company is growing quickly and experiencing a lot of the pains that go along with it. The different platforms and technologies that are being acquired are merging into one over time, and the transition is very rocky. The workload is extremely high, with employees overworked and expected to try to individually manage 40+ trouble tickets per day, on top of fielding inbound calls (which lead to additional tickets).

The training process is practically non-existent. New hires are given very basic formal instruction, if even that, then expected to pick up everything else along the way. The new products and applications being added constantly are rarely, if ever, included in any training, and often the team is not even made aware they are supposed to be supporting them until a call comes in about it. There are attempts to ease people into the job somewhat by giving a longer time period to work the easier tickets and not being expected to take calls right away, but it's very inconsistent, and some new hires end up doing simple ticket management for months while the rest of the team takes the brunt of the workload. The constant refrain is to ask your co-workers for help, but they are also constantly busy and any training has to depend on how knowledgeable the specific person available to help you is on the subject. Incorrect information will often be spread due to lack of any formalized knowledge or procedures, and supervisors and management do not take charge of making sure this is corrected, or taught correctly in the first place.

Additionally, the systems you need to learn are very specific and require a lot of specialized training, which again is expected to be picked up along the way in bits and pieces.

A lot of the actual work ends up dealing with the specific platforms and can get repetitive and narrow in focus. There are chances to use networking and technical skills, but rarely ever enough time to actually dig into problems and do real troubleshooting, as there is constant pressure to handle all the other issues that are constantly happening and taking calls all the time. As a result, advancement opportunities are rather sparse, as if you do a good job they will want to keep you in your current position.
advice_to_mgmt: Invest in actual training and processes, this will keep the people who are actually motivated and hard working who want to learn and do well, rather than burning through people and constantly hiring more while letting others who have figured out how to do so coast along with doing the minimum.

review_title: Making the transition to a technology company
pros: Excellent benefits, fair amount of FDO, access to a large pool of resources due to the size of the company, lot of places to work and lots of opportunity to change roles within the company. Additionally, Vonage is really making an effort to make the shift from a consumer telephone company to a multi-market communications technology company, and are very open to new ideas and new technology.
cons: Because of this transition, there is a lot of confusion over process, especially since different parts of the company are using various forms of project managment. Most of the company has a waterfall mind-set, and this causes a lot of pain for the technology branch of the company that is trying to make the transformation to agile workflows. My experience has typically been that process is favored over productivity. This is partly due to the fact that a company value is unity, and getting everybody into the same workflow is part of the working out of that value. So this is a good and a bad thing, but there are a lot of growing pains nonetheless.
advice_to_mgmt: I would highly recommend that if unity is truly a value at Vonage, that you guys focus on good communication and mentoring for your upper and middle management. All of the bad things that I've experienced at Vonage could be easily solved by a quick 5 minute phone call with someone giving me a heads-up, or a department meeting to discuss an overview to a new process change. Additionally, things break down when some of the company is speaking in terms of story points, and other parts of the company are talking about milestones. Everybody has to buy in to the project management technique of choice, or the disparity causes more harm than good.

The management shows special treatment to some employees and gives them leads from former employees and they also give them specialized lists to increase their chances of passing a lead. Was told that my yearly earnings would be around 45-50k thats laughable. I'm in the top ten of the employees in our department and the highest "commission" check i have received is 400 dollars. There is rarely any room for advancement.

pros: The compensation for the job is good. They also have a snack room filled with an assortment of drinks and food.
cons:
Vonage has a lot of issues. In my interview, I was never informed that I would be working in a call call-like environment and that we didn't really do that many technical activities. I had been informed we would do more networking and that the company would actively work to help you advance. As time went by, my supervisors kept stating they would let me shadow another department, but never did. The job I have involves taking call after call. The system is setup poorly so that some techs game the system by closing tickets before the issue has been resolved and telling the customer to just open a new ticket, thereby, making their metrics look better. These technicians receive a scolding, but continue to create more work.

The metrics that Vonage has are hard to meet if you aren't closing password reset tickets, closing tickets without verifying that the customer is satisfied, or just flat out game the system. It gives the impression that Vonage cares for little else, but numbers since they make little effort to deal with the problem of cheating. Employees are even sometimes rewarded with PTO if they close the most tickets even by cheating!

They also do not train us and leave us work amongst the techs to figure out a technology that no one told us we would be supporting. Even after merging with another company, we received zero training on that company's technology, while the other company received training on our's. We have repeatedly asked management for training and they stated that we should just ask our peers. Instead, we are left floundering and wasting time unsure of what we are doing.

There is no option to work from home (despite the fact that we are running out of seats for our technicians), but Sales can do so. We are constantly cleaning up Sales' mess when they tell the customer that certain things can be done when they can't due to Sales trying to meet their numbers.

Vonage is constantly having outages, so we are often dealing with angry customers. It is frustrating when the higher-ups, including the CEO, brag about how great Vonage is when Support sees little improvements in infrastructure, in training, in benefits for the Support team, in standardized processes, among other things. All Vonage cares about are their Sales departments and it shows with all of the parties and the perks they are given.
advice_to_mgmt: Actually, train your employees instead of leaving them to fend for themselves. Listen to your employees, make standardized processes (this way everyone knows what they are doing), provide a path to advancement and career opportunities to keep people interested, have each of the teams communicate more, so that we work as a cohesive unit.

review_title: Poor Management, Poor Choices, Poor Policy, Poor Healthcare Benefits
pros: The coworkers. Never found a better group of technicians to work with. They make the company somewhat tolerable. The Senior technicians dont look down on the technicians but instead work to fix the issues you have.
cons:
Worked there for just over a year and the company went from an awesome place to work for to what can only be called 'A Resume Stain' Im sure you know the companies, when someone looks at your resume and says "Oh worked there...Im sorry for your pain". Poor management that spends more time lying to the techs than actually fixing problems.

Changes to Work Force Management and to Compliancy make actually helping the customer impossible. The Management believes you should be able to fix a companies network, and setup phones in less than 18 minutes. This leaves technicians to do the bare minimum to make sure they stay within compliancy or you are written up, fired, or stripped of work from home.

Constantly being told there are promotion prospects but when promotions come up they are given to people outside the company with no clue how to manage a tech team or worse, sent from the main office to institute more draconian policies that make little or no sense. This is what is called 'Glass Ceiling' and with the poor management lying every time a prospect comes up it makes the techs feel under appreciated.

We are expected to follow QA to make sure we are doing the job right but have no way of seeing the score unless you screw up. This makes it impossible to actually improve yourself. They instituted a new QA system, still cant see anything but now are threatening immediate failures if certain things happen such as communicate in Hiphat(means of getting help) talk to someone else during a call.

The goal of Homedale,NJ (main office), is to close out the Atlanta office. They are constantly place techs in the queue from the main office after bare minimum of training and they tend to cause more problems than solve. Poor performance of these people cause more problems.

Poor testing has caused large gaps of time on companies systems where they cant use part or all of the phone system. Prior to Main office jumping in and 'helping' queues were usually 5-10 techs waiting on a call which made talking to a technician quick and efficient. After the 'helping hand' we usually have 20 - 100 people on hold with 15 minute wait times in the busy part of the day.

The company is hemorrhaging technicians and talent. They dont seem too inclined to fix the issue but instead blame everything but the poor management practices.

With in the next 2 years the company will be phased to an india call center due to cost.
If you are a tech. dont bother. If you are a company dont jump in with them its not worth the cost you will incur to your company to be treated this way.

Now we come to Healthcare. About 3 months ago they decided to change healthcare coverage. Those who took HSA to offset costs are still over a month behind on the money. Apparently the not so bright powers that be decided to implement and not have anything in place to transfer money. At present there are quite a few diabetics and other people with medical needs that need prescriptions filled constantly. This is all coming out of pocket since Vonage stole the money out of the HSA accounts. They promise it will be 'fixed' but unless you threaten to report them nothing gets done. Technically they are working on the issue and will fix this...but three months is long enough. Most people believe that if the money is not available due to misappropriation it is theft. Vonage beleive it is a slight inconvenience. I have had to contact the VA on several occasions to get prescriptions filled. Luckily they have stepped up to help me fill the prescriptions i need to function. It really is amazing that the VA has a more reliable healthcare plan they Vonage does.

All in all dont work here. There are better jobs and right now the tech department is looking like a ghost town. They cant keep techs due to policy and outright mistreatment. Their goal is to gut the Atlanta office and move it overseas and to leased call centers where cost is reduced. They dont care about employees or customers at this point.
advice_to_mgmt:
Quit, you cause most of the problems in the company.
Fire any supervisor who cant pass the standard tech training test every tech takes to get in. Start promoting from within, a tech works better if he knows he has a place to go and a goal to work for. When you kill off incentives and promotions it shows them you feel they are worthless and not worth your time.

Actually there is not much you can do...this dog aint gonna hunt anymore. the damage is done.

review_title: Legacy telecom company that is trying to continue to be true to its customers and provide new options for growth.
pros: There are good people at the operational and day-to-day team level. I really enjoy working with my team and many other parts of the organization. There are a number of teams that want to do what's best for the organization and try to be successful. The building, facilities, and amenities are also very nice. Its a very open space, WiFi everywhere so you aren't confined to your desk. Very good coffee and cafeteria and an onsite gym open early and late are both pluses.
cons:
There is difficulty with the company culture as a number of teams are stuck in the past of how they operate without much willingness to change. At heart its a software company that has to move faster to stay up with competitors. There is also a difficult cultural environment that is drive from executive where differences of opinion or simple facts about the market or a product are perceived as a threat or are discarded. Any company has resource issues, but the inability for some executive to listen to solutions on these issues or change the company's culture led to a number of good people leaving the organization in frustration.

The location (Holmdel, NJ) is a difficult one if you don't live in Monmouth or the surrounding counties. Myself, my VP and a number of my team members and senior management live in the NYC area. The commute for some is 2+ hours depending on traffic. It also becomes very difficult to recruit good talent because of the location.
advice_to_mgmt:
There has been a recent change in executive management at the company and overall it seems like a good change for the direction of the company and the overall culture. The company needs a different outlet than the legacy home phone replacement business and the new leadership should give some new direction on what the future strategy will be for the company outside of the traditional revenue models.

I did enjoy a lot of my time here, learned a great deal, and am appreciative of the overall experience.

pros: Employee appreciation week, nice office/building

Blatant display of favoritism, management is inexperienced, sub-par sales training, low compensation, too much emphasis on the # of calls made...etc.

This position is really only for young inexperienced people. Anyone with a legitimate sales background will be absolutely floored by the inefficient sales model and lack of experience from supervisors. The management team are all friends (not just friendly, but actual friends), so you have to be extremely careful about what you say and to whom. They will tell you that the SDR position is "only for about 2-3 months, and then you can get promoted to a closer", but this is a LIE. You will find out that this is actually meant to be a year long position, and anyone who does happen to get promoted did so simply due to favoritism. They track the # of calls made each day (150 is the goal) as well as talk time, AND they listen in on your calls...however not all supervisors will actually provide genuine feedback regarding the calls they listen to...some just listen in and TRY to give you advice, however the "advice" is anything but constructive.
advice_to_mgmt: I suggest that upper management sincerely re-evaluate promoting and employing friends. The supervisors are simply not qualified for their role and are unable to effectively manage and coach such a large group of people. You need quality, experienced professionals who can coach and develop top talent.

pros:
My early years were great, where it was definitely an environment of fun and team.
Most of the people are great and fun to work with.
They sometimes provide activities & events to lift morale.
Decent benefits and vacation days.
Community Volunteer program.
Onsite Cafeteria w/$100 monthly meal allowance (although, you will grow tired of the food very quickly because it's the same menu every month)
cons:
If you are promoted from within, you will be grossly underpaid. HR will acknowledge that you are underpaid, but then never do anything to correct your paycheck. Positions aren't given to the best candidates, instead promotions are handled politically.

Lack of communication across the company, especially to the Care Organization when products are being launched, which often lead to poor rushed roll outs where most individuals are not prepared because most information is missing up until a few days before roll out.

The company claims to take employee feedback, but I couldn't tell you the last time I saw an employee suggestion that was acted upon. There's an annual "Great Place to Work" Survey, which most people are told how to answer.

Management does not always appear to support the worker or their growth. You will be given a yearly goal to improve your skills, however when you present your manager with options, they are often declined because of budgetary reason and are instead told to just read articles on the internet

The only way the company is able to make money is to consistently raise prices on existing customers. Poor marketing department that doesn't know how to attract new customers, which is causing tenured customers to leave due to raising rates. It's like they don't understand how business works.

A LOT of layoffs recently, and the process by which people are laid off appears backwards. Many of the harder workers with strong work ethics are laid off, while the people whose job function you couldn't explain no matter how hard you try because it's a made-up role or people who truly are poor performers are kept on board. When they let you go, they tell you that you no longer match the job description, but when you ask for the new job description, it's what you are currently doing.
advice_to_mgmt:
Take a good look at the entire organization - do you really have the right people in the right roles? (The answer is No)

Re-evaluate your marketing program and learn how your consumers really utilize phone service in this day-and-age.

If you are going to do layoffs, lay off the correct people - there are plenty of people there who don't bring value to the organization.

review_title: RUN!!! Huge mistake taking a job here!
pros: Other than a very select few people, there is not a single pro I can give you to ever work here. Do yourself a favor and just don't apply or accept an offer here!
cons:
This is the most unprofessional, disrespectful joke of a company I have ever worked for! I decided to leave within a month of being there and eventually left without another job lined up after less than 1 year there. There is no management, leadership and the concern is more with who to blame and doing the same things over and over with no results then the want for progress or success.

I gave more than 2 weeks notice and agreed to staying a couple weeks longer after being asked by 1 of the very few people there I respect. I wanted to leave knowing I was professional until the end and left delivering more than any other person on my team including my boss.

I was recently offered a new job and after multiple attempts by my new company to verify my employment they contacted me for help. After multiple attempts myself and eventually a phone conversation with my old HR rep, who agreed to get it done by the next day....you guessed it...still nothing! Thank goodness I keep my own records and was able to provide the verification myself. However by this time I missed my scheduled start date and was made to wait a month for the next orientation.

Not only are they unprofessional while you work there, they continue that practice even after you have left.

I wouldn't recommend anyone apply or work here!!

pros: Good work environment, good mix of technology, nice people. Holmdel its their headquarters so all job functions are represented. Food credit for the cafe each month, and decent gym (membership deducted from paycheck).
cons: Vonage is trying to stay relevant in a tough competitive landscape. Flat revenue / growth. Product ideas are over-debated within senior leadership.
advice_to_mgmt: Be willing to take more risks and be more agile in product definition.

review_title: Great pay and hours bad management and customer support

advice_to_mgmt: If you have someone who's job is to buy from wal-mart have supervisors keep better tabs on Wal-Mart inventory. Instead of learning late that inventory is incorrect and assuming theft.

review_title: No market growth and not self-aware enough to improve
pros:
- Nice campus and facilities
- Most people try to be nice
cons:
- The technology and services are antiquated and basic
- Corporate culture is highly political and based on "getting along" rather than results
- There's a lot of residual AT&T and other "big company" employees who bring a "dinosaur" mentality to everything - especially those with NO telecom background
- Changes are at glacial speed; all processes require political correctness and consensus of even irrelevant parties, stand-alone decisions are punished
- Has an unrealistic view of itself as bigger, more savvy and "cutting edge" than they are
- High tolerance for incompetence from those "tenured" - the Peter Principle at it's finest
advice_to_mgmt: Remind yourselves that you are a telecom, and take a look at what success in the industry looks like; agile, aggressive, and with deep technical skills. Finely tuned back-office operations are important, but NOT what makes customers whip out their credit cards to sign up. You know you've plateaued, and you know you need to change but you can't have "Agents of Change" be or act like those that got you stuck in the first place.

pros: Vonage tends to have a family atmosphere that can be great if you can adapt and work well with others. You get to work with many different technologies and systems that you may not get exposure to elsewhere

review_title: Took away some good things but overall consistently lacked training, development and professionalism

Growth opportunity if you can navigate the shark infested waters
Small circle strong leaders
Employees take are of each other

Unprofessional behavior at the management level

advice_to_mgmt: If you really want to retain good talent look at your employees from the mgr level. Your operations managers spend more time covering themselves and finding out who is the right person to kiss up to then managing day to day and developing the talent they have working under them. Employee feedback is treated as something to move off a check list then to really dig down and fix the issue. Too many use a band aid approach and are rewarded for it daily.

review_title: A company run on wishful thinking
pros: A cafe inside the building. Pay is decent.
cons: Long term success at Vonage requires learning how to blame someone else for your problems. This is mostly done through lying and intimidation. The longer you stay there, the more you realize that your time will eventually run out, as someone else will eventually do you in. All decision-making appears to be based on wishful thinking; hope overrides fact. When projects fail, the failure is often redefined as success, ensuring that those in charge continue to be covered in glory.
advice_to_mgmt: Jettison all middle management; establish control over IT contractors. Upper management appear to be decent business people but are technically clueless, so they cannot tell when middle management misleads, which is often.

review_title: Sad unethical company with terrible management

review_title: Vonage will help you grow, but slowly wears you down if you stay too long.
pros: Great co-workers, and a great working environment, or was. Depending on your team and manager, tons of training opportunities.
cons: So many levels of management, so many levels of reviews on projects. Unless a friend was desperate, I would advise them to find employment elsewhere.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop adding so many levels of complexity to everything. Don't change the culture to fit in with where you used to work. You came here to work, we didnt come to you. Flexible schedules is a great offset to lower than industry pay or only 2% annual increases.

review_title: Incredible career growth experience for me
pros: Great Place to work, I've learned more than i could've ever expected
cons: no cons i can think of at this time

pros: $100/month meal allowance, access to management, flexibility, freedom to develop what I thought was necessary, my manager was not the micro-management type but was available when I needed him to be
cons: Advancement was slow, upper management was short-sighted, far too political for my taste, SharePoint was brought in and in-house application development was outsourced
advice_to_mgmt: Abandon SharePoint and keep development in-house. You had a lot of talented managers and developers but many have been eliminated due to "position elimination". I have kept in touch with many former co-workers and find that a considerable number of the best people have moved on or are looking to. You need to stop looking at the bottom line and get back the way things were in 2006 thru 2008.

As for career growth, the only growth is if you come in from the outside, get a better titled then jump ship. Internal growth is too tough. You get the chance to work for another department off the phones for 6 months then you are sent back, sometimes with no goals and then managed out.

review_title: Completely dysfunctional. Management is confused from the top down.

All that matters to these departments is the politics. So long as each department can collect supporting metrics to point the finger elsewhere, they are happy. It's rare to see honest teamwork.
advice_to_mgmt: Streamline the organization. A flatter org chart would give everyone more influence and encourage people to work together instead of hiding in their silos behind metrics.

pros: benefits and people are the best

Focus and direction can change. In fact, this company embraces change, and change is consistent. Projects are VERY fast-paced.

pros: free food, clean toilets, plenty of parking and friendly staff.

The place is a huge revolving door. There is no real HR. They measure employee performance by analyzing the fake surveys they receive from their customers. The management gets paid to act like they care. THEY DO NOT DRUG TEST. Great clean toilets and they hand you 5$ for lunch. Sticking your head in the wall for $14.99 plus tax sounds good at Vonage.
advice_to_mgmt: LEARN HOW TO MANAGE AND DEVELOP SOFTWARE THAT WORKS. ENGLISH IS A BIG PLUS.

pros: NIce building. Lots of nice people. Most seem to really care about how their job affects the company. Pay is decent but sometimes raises were extremely poor. In house Starbucks was great. Fun stuff all the time like bbq's, department festivities (birthdays, holidays). Lots of collaboration between teams to get things done.
cons: Upper management isn't very proactive and waits to tackle problems after they've had a severe financial impact. Frustrating for employees who care and voice concerns early with no response. "Friends and favorites" get promoted more often. I guess that goes for any company but politics shouldn't supercede ability. Customer service agents seem to be abused by being forced to use extra skills without xtra ecompensation but thats hearsay. Some mean people. Again, thats everywhere. Benefits were horribly expensive for family but that seems to be the norm with a lot of companies these days.
advice_to_mgmt: Stop giving everything away for free! Unlimited Unlimited Unlimited?? Limit things for goodness sake! Contribute to employee benefit premiums. Stop spending money on tee shirts, pens and other branded nonsense and start putting that money to help employees live better lives in this economy. Every type of employee.

pros: Excellent benefits package. Good offices. Onsite gym and coffee bar.
cons: Poor management, lack of communication, given very limited tools to solve customer problems.

pros: Many different lateral moves are available

advice_to_mgmt: Be competitive in the market

pros: The only thing Vonage has going for them that other tech support jobs do not is the $100/month they give everyone to spend on food in their cafeteria.
cons:
Senior management has *NO IDEA* what goes on with the "regular" employees or the company in general. There is very little communication between the top level and the bottom level, and oftentimes the bottom level is completely left out of company-wide meetings due to "scheduling conflicts".
The attendance policy for the call floor does not leave any room whatsoever for an actual sickness or injury. Employees can call out sick three days in 6 months and get fired the fourth time.
The company has no way of polling or extracting necessary information from their own database of customer calls. If the company needs to find out information about a certain topic, each call center agent is required to fill out additional forms and/or spreadsheets *while on the phone with a customer* that gets consolidated and sent up the ladder.
advice_to_mgmt: Talk to your employees. Spend time on the call floor, or at least actively listen to the calls going on. Come up with a way of monitoring customers' call quality.

review_title: Not highly recommended for job advancement

They do not do raises based on performances, and bonuses are scaled low. Vonage also does not have much in terms of self developing yourself, poor onsite training.
advice_to_mgmt: Take a look at what you have on hand. Employees who year in and out receive great reviews are not properly rewarded. Those who are there for the company, not the money - dont receive the recognition they should receive.

Agents are the backbone of the business, but they ALWAYS get the short end of the stick. Not a good place to work, even on a part-time basis.
advice_to_mgmt: The people hired with authority to make change, should also have a double dose of integrity.

advice_to_mgmt: Need to be more in tune with how the industry is headed.

pros:

The secret to Vonage is to not plan on staying - get in -get some great experience - and get out - 12 to 18 mos.
cons: The company is largely run like a mafia-style family - in virtually every sense of the word. Watch the Soprano's - its extremely similar on many levels.
advice_to_mgmt: None.

review_title: Opportunity to make a big impact but make sure you probe on senior leadership depth

cons: Company has run into a lot of bad luck, which has driven down morale. The location in Holmdel, NJ makes it hard to recruit and retain top young talent. The CEO is brilliant but still needs to learn how to delegate and empower others. While the new Holmdel facility is nice, the company seems to skimp a bit on vacation benefits.
advice_to_mgmt: Focus on recruiting and empowering the best talent. Create an environment which is a true meritocracy of ideas. Don't skimp on compensation and benefits.

review_title: Fun place to work for a workaholic.

advice_to_mgmt: I don't have any particular advice. It was a fun place to work when they had their act together. Treat people with respect all the time.

review_title: A great place for professional growth
pros:
* Vonage invests heavily in their employees' professional growth - providing the freedom to explore new technologies and attend conferences such as UX Salon, UXI, etc.
* There are a lot of company activities such as Hackathons, Good Deeds Day, Happy Hours every week, Innovation Days...
* Unlike companies where every person is supposed to do his small part and keep their heads down, at Vonage employees are urged and expected to participate in making the company a better place. Working in an open space ensures that we are constantly communicating and collaborating.
* Leaders that are worth looking up to, who inspire high quality work.
cons: The Israeli Vonage branch is still a part of the Vonage corporate, and some procedures still have to go through the Headquarters, which sometimes makes progress difficult. But with time as the Israeli branch grows, it becomes better.

pros:
* A true meritocracy in the engineering department: your title doesn't matter, if you can do an awesome job and be accountable, you will get the opportunity to accomplish huge things and learn a ton.
* Startup culture: deliver quickly, touch production frequently, work hard and have fun while doing it.
* The R&D center is composed of a group of extremely talented individuals that are also team players.
* This company really invests in its employees, sending them to global conferences such as Google IO, WWDC, AWS Reinvent etc.
And hosts group trainings such as "innovation days" hackathons and others.
cons: It is still a pretty big company and as such there is some level of bureaucracy at times, whether it is the need to complete PCI/SOX/whatever compliance tests or the need to jump through certain hoops to justify budgetary needs etc.
advice_to_mgmt:
Keep on investing in talent acquisition and talent management.
It is probably the most important investment a company can make.
This alone will drive the company to greatness.

review_title: All in all a great company to work for, even if there's a few "bugs" that need to be worked out.
pros: The pay rate is supurb compaired to other companies for my job type. The company itself is still in its infancy but so far has built up a good client base and there's deffinatly a room for growth somewhere down the line. The free lunches we get on Friday is a great bonus compared to a lot of other companies out there. The people and management are easy to speak to but sometimes difficult to get anything done when a change needs to be made. Its one of a few companies that I can say im happy to be working for.
cons: The location in Canada is not the easiest to get to, Sometimes the multiculturism of the hiring makes it hard to relate to some of the other employee's who work here. People in the higher positions have a high turn around rate so its hard to figure out who's in what position. As of right now there isnt to much room for growth if your in a lower tier position. Some of the application we use are quite slow and need to be updated to a more modern type system. All in all still a good employer.
advice_to_mgmt: Improve the systems were working on. Listen more closely to the employee's. Work out some of the bugs in the product to improve the customers use of the system. Spend more time on the backbone of the system and devices.
